occurrences.line_text: But when his meane estate he did reuew,
When the bright sunne his beams thereon doth beat;
When so the froward skye began to lowre:
When Titan faire his beames did display,
When she for ought him sharpely did reproue,
But when in none of all these she him got,
Whom when as Venus saw so sore displeased,
Lucinaes aide: which when they both perceiued,
Where most she wonnes, whe[n] she on earth does dwel.
Which when as forme and feature it does ketch,
Ne when the life decayes, and forme does fade,
When walking through the Gardin, them she spyde,
But she her selfe, when euer that she will,
Who when he hath with spoiles and cruelty
In which when she to perfect ripenesse grew,
But past awhile, when she fit season saw
Who when too late awaking, well they kent,
Tho when all other helpes she saw to faile,
Whom when the fearefull Damzell nigh espide,
But when his force gan faile, his pace gan wex areare.
But forward gallopt fast; which when he spyde,
Which when his cruell enimy espyde,
She bore him fast away. Which when the knight,
Whom when as nigh approching she espyde,
But still when him at hand she did espy,
But when he stayd, to flight againe she did her take.
Which when she saw, more bent to eke my smartes,
But was as farre at last, as when I first begon.
Now when the Beast, which by her wicked art
But when he saw himselfe free from poursute,
At last when droncke with drowsinesse, he woke,
But when he saw that blazing beauties beame,
But when her well auizing, he perceiued
Where be ye now, when she is nigh defild
Of falshood or of slouth, when most it may behoue.
Who when those pittifull outcries he heard,
But when she looked vp, to weet, what wight
Was Florimell, when Proteus she did see thereby.
But when all this he nothing saw preuaile,
But when with feare, nor fauour, nor with all
Which words when Paridell had heard, his hew
T'haue seene, (quoth he) when as a monstrous beast
Can guilen Argus, when she list misdonne?
Then when he was defide, in coward corner ly.
Then when they were accorded from the fray,
To tucke about her short, when she did ryde,
And euer and anone, when none was ware,
And when so of his hand the pledge she raught,
Now when of meats and drinks they had their fill,
But after when both nations gan to striue,
When so in open place, and commune bord,
But when apart (if euer her apart)
Tho when againe he him bethought to liue,
When chaunst Malbecco busie be elsewhere,
As Hellene, when she saw aloft appeare
But when againe he backward cast his eye,
Ay when to him she cryde, to her he turnd,
But when he marked, how his money burnd,
Still when he mused on his late mischiefe,
At last when sorrow he saw booted nought,
Whom such when as Malbecco spyed clere,
But went his way; whom when he passed kend,
Now when amid the thickest woods they were,
Which when Malbecco saw, out of his bush
At night, when all they went to sleepe, he vewd,
When one so oft a night did ring his matins bell.
When wearie of their sport to sleepe they fell,
Where when he found it not (for Trompart bace
Ne banck nor bush could stay him, when he sped
Whom when as Britomart beheld behind
Whom when the Gyaunt saw, he soone resinde
Which when she heard, and saw the ghastly fit,
Once, when he with Asterie did scape,
Againe, when as the Troiane boy so faire
And like a fire, when he Aegin' assayd:
A shepheard, when Mnemosyne he catcht:
When she with Mars was meynt in ioyfulnesse:
When for to compasse Philliras hard loue,
When her discolourd bow she spreds through heauens hight.
With which he shot at randon, when him list,
Tho when as chearelesse Night ycouered had
Expecting euer, when some foe she might descry.
And when it ceast, shrill trompets loud did bray,
And when they ceast, it gan againe to play,
To great Alcides, that when as he dyde,
His feeble steps, which shrunke, when hard theron he lay.
And his owne armes when glittering he did spy,
When her weake feete could scarcely her sustaine,
For to efforce, when charmes had closed it afore.
When that same Maske againe should forth arize.
Then when the second watch was almost past,
Tho when she felt her selfe to be vnbound,
But when the victoresse arriued there,
But he sad man, when he had long in drede
A perilous fight when he with force her brought
When her from deadly thraldome he redeemed,
Such when those Knights and Ladies all about
But none to issue forth when one is in:
As plaine as at the first, when they were fresh and greene.
Which when to ripenesse due they growen arre,
For life it is to her, when others sterue
And both misplast; that when th'one forward yode,
Now when this gallant with his goodly crew,
Whom when as Paridel more plaine beheld,
Which when his other companie beheld,
Whom when as Blandamour approching nie,
Which when he thought, it grieued him full sore,
As when two billowes in the Irish sowndes,
Which when as Blandamour beheld, he sayd,
Such is thy wont, that still when any Knight
Which when as Scudamour did heare, his heart
Was thrild with inward griefe, as when in chace
So stood Sir Scudamour, when this he heard,
Such as was Orpheus, that when strife was growen
That when the wicked feend his Lord tormented,
Which when as Blandamour, whose fancie light
And euer when his passion is allayd,
Well know'st thou, whe[n] we friendship first did sweare,
As when two warlike Brigandines at sea,
But when as she her selfe was lost and gone,
When they the reason of his words had hard,
One day, when all that troupe of warlike wooers
Thereto she was right faire, when so her face
Which when their mother saw, she gan to dout
And when at last she had beheld her fill,
That when she saw, it did her much amate,
Graunt this, that when ye shred with fatall knife
And when the next shall likewise ended bee,
But euermore, when she fit time could fynd,
Whom so dismayd when Cambell had espide,
Whom when on ground his brother next beheld,
As when two Tygers prickt with hungers rage,
As when a Vulture greedie of his pray,
Which faire aduenture when Cambello spide,
With double life, and griefe, which when he felt,
Which when for want of breath gan to abate,
But when the floud is spent, then backe againe
Still when as he enfeebled was, him cherisht,
As fresh as when it first was planted in the soyle.
Which when as all the lookers on beheld,
Which when she saw, downe on the bloudy plaine
But when as all might nought with them preuaile,
When all men saw this sudden change of things,
All which, when gentle Canacee beheld,
Where when she saw that cruell war so ended,
Thus when they all accorded goodly were,
To stirre vp strife, when most vs needeth rest,
When who so list to fight, may fight his fill,
Which when the noble Ferramont espide,
When as he saw the mercilesse affray
That doubly did him grieue, when so himselfe he found.
When all vnwares he felt an hideous sway
Whereof when newes to Triamond was brought,
As when two greedy Wolues doe breake by force
The last day came, when all those knightes againe
And when his speare was brust, his sword he drew,
But when they could not learne it by no wize,
All which when Blandamour from end to end
Like as in sommers day when raging heat
But layd aside, when so she vsd her looser sport.
When first he loued her with heart entire,
The same one day, when she her selfe disposd
But when they thought it fast, eftsoones it was vntide.
Which when that scornefull Squire of Dames did vew,
Whom when the rest did see her to refuse,
Which troublous stirre when Satyrane auiz'd:
Then when she long had lookt vpon each one,
Which when they all beheld they chaft and rag'd,
Whom, when he was vnto her selfe most nie,
Which when that warriour saw, he said no more,
When gentle sleepe his heauie eyes would close;
And euermore, when he to sleepe did thinke,
And euermore, when he began to winke,
When euer he this way shall passe by day or night.
When Scudamour heard mention of that speare,
It shall not fayle, when so ye shall it need.
Who[m] when they nigh approcht, they plaine descryde
At length when as he saw her hastie heat
Which when as Scudamour, who now abrayd,
And drawing nigh, when as he plaine descride
When Britomart with sharpe auizefull eye
But euer when his visage she beheld,
But when in vaine to fight she oft assayd,
But brought forth speeches myld, when she would haue missayd.
When Glauce thus gan wisely all vpknit;
But when as I did out of sleepe abray,
When Scudamour those heauie tydings heard,
Tho when they had long time there taken rest,
Mongst Knights, when on aduentures they did ride,
At last when all her speeches she had spent,
When suddenly behind her backe she heard
And raught downe to his waste, when vp he stood,
Whilest he in armes her bore; but when she felt
Then when she lookt about, and nothing found
Vntride, is lesse then when thou shalt it try:
Whose bodies chast, when euer in his powre
For euer when he burnt in lustfull fire,
Which when as fearefull Amoret perceiued,
And euermore when with regardfull sight
For euer when the Squire his iauelin shooke,
And made him oft, when he would strike, forbeare;
Whom when that theefe approching nigh espide,
As when Latonaes daughter cruell kynde,
Whom when on ground she groueling saw to rowle,
Which when she saw, with sodaine glauncing eye,
And follow'd fast: but when he came in sight,
And euermore, when he did grace entreat,
At last when long he follow'd had in vaine,
And euer when the Prince vnto him spake,
When he it heard, and how the ground he kist,
Tho when he long had marked his demeanor,
All vnawares the bird, when she did find
But when as long he looked had in vaine,
And euer when she nigh approcht, the Doue
Whom when she saw in wretched weedes disguiz'd,
When so he heard her say, eftsoones he brake
That when your pleasure is to deeme aright,
Whom when the Prince beheld, he gan to rew
Tho when they both recouered were right well,
At which he wondred much, when all those signes he fond.
But when as nought according to his mind
So when that forrest they had passed well,
Here well I weene, when as these rimes be red
But when the world woxe old, it woxe warre old
At last when they were passed out of sight,
Where when he saw the Prince in armour bright,
But when he to himselfe returnd againe,
Which when that Squire beheld, he woxe full glad
To which when he according did repaire,
Whereof when tydings came vnto mine eare,
When all three kinds of loue together meet,
Whom when the watch, that kept continuall ward
Whence being forth produc'd, when she perceiued
But when of him no aunswere she receiued,
But when a while they had together beene,
Began to doubt, when she them saw embrace,
And eke the Prince, when as he them auized,
Thus when the Prince had perfectly compylde
As when Dan AEolus in great displeasure,
As when two Barkes, this caried with the tide,
Faint friends when they fall out, most cruell fomen bee.
As when an eager mastiffe once doth proue
Whom when the Briton Prince a farre beheld
Which when I red, my heart did inly earne,
Me when as he had priuily espide,
Which when he saw, the glaiue which he did wield
Which when as I, that neuer tasted blis,
And when thou spredst thy mantle forth on hie,
Wayting when as the Antheme should be sung on hye.
Like to the Morne, when first her shyning face
On which when Cupid with his killing bow
Whom when I saw with amiable grace
When as he saw me, maugre all his powre,
Then Cerberus, when Orpheus did recoure
For when as neither gifts nor graces kind
Which Britomart him gaue, when he did her prouoke.
And many herbes did vse. But when as nought
Through which, when Paris brought his famous prise
When to Ioues pallace she doth take her way;
The surging seas, when they do sorest rage,
The manner of the Gods when they at banquet bee.
And count my cares, when none is nigh to heare,
Will yeeld, but when my piteous plaints he heares,
And when my weary ghost with griefe outworne,
All which complaint when Marinell had heard,
At last when as no meanes he could inuent,
Which when his mother saw, she in her mind
Which when he had vnto his mother told,
When he in place his dearest loue did spy;
When as mans age was in his freshest prime,
When good was onely for it selfe desyred,
When Iustice was not for most meed outhyred,
When so it needs with rigour to dispence.
When so he list in wrath lift vp his steely brand.
Well prou'd in that same day, when Ioue those Gyants quelled.
Now when the world with sinne gan to abound,
But when she parted hence, she left her groome
When as they saw a Squire in squallid weed,
Which when his Ladie saw, she follow'd fast,
Who mou'd no more therewith, then when a rocke
That when he wak't out of his warelesse paine,
When to the place they came, where Artegall
When as he saw she should be cut in twaine,
True loue despiseth shame, when life is cald in dread.
Whom when so willing Artegall perceaued;
Who when he saw it bootelesse to resist,
But of her health when Artegall did heare,
And askt him where, and when her bridale cheare
Which when the Pagan saw, he wexed wroth,
Which oddes when as Sir Artegall espide,
As when a Dolphin and a Sele are met,
Vppon the Castle wall, and when she saw
But when as yet she saw him to proceede,
All which when Talus throughly had perfourmed,
All which when Artegall did see, and heare,
What wrong then is it, if that when they die,
Which when he saw, he greatly grew in rage,
Whom when so lewdly minded Talus found,
That when the people, which had there about
In warlike wise, when Artegall did vew,
But when at them he with his flaile gan lay,
As when a Faulcon hath with nimble flight
When Talus saw they all the field forsooke
So when as fortune all her spight hath showne,
When all men had with full satietie
Where when he vnderstood by common fame,
Which when he had perform'd, then backe againe
Whom when discouered they had throughly eide,
Which when as Marinell beheld likewise,
As when two sunnes appeare in the azure skye,
So stood Sir Marinell, when he had seene
All which when Artegall, who all this while
When they are all restor'd, thou shalt rest in disgrace.
Whom when as all the people such did vew,
As when the daughter of Thaumantes faire,
Which when as all that present were, beheld,
Which troublous stirre when Artegall perceiued,
And when as he him nam'd, for ioy he brake
Now when these counterfeits were thus vncased
That when as time to Artegall shall tend,
When Artegall arriuing happily,
But now when Philtra saw my lands decay,
When as the paine of death she tasted had,
When they thus ended had, the Knight began;
When he his sentence thus pronounced had,
When as their sharpe contention he had ceased,
To whom when he approched neare in sight,
Now when as Artegall arriu'd in place,
But when she saw at last, that he ne would
Which when as Radigund there comming heard,
But Radigund her selfe, when she espide
As when a Beare hath seiz'd her cruell clawes
Whom when as Artegall in that distresse
But when as daies faire shinie-beame, yclowded
When thus the field was voided all away,
Vp to her ham, but when she list, it raught
Whom when he saw before his foote prostrated,
But when as he discouered had her face,
But when they thought on Talus hands to lay,
When they haue shaken off the shamefast band,
At last when long she struggled had in vaine,
From time to time, when thou it best shalt see,
Which when the cruell Amazon perceiued,
Nathlesse when calmed was her furious heat,
When thou hast all this doen, then bring me newes
Yet when she reckned them, still drawing neare,
But when as yet she saw him not returne,
One day, when as she long had sought for ease
Who when he nigh approcht, shee mote arede
But when she had with such vnquiet fits
All which when she with hard enduraunce had
That gaue none other place. Which when as hee
Which when their Host perceiu'd, right discontent
I wote when ye did watch both night and day
As when the flashing Leuin haps to light
Vnto whose temple when as Britomart
Whose goodly building when she did behould,
Such was the Goddesse; whom when Britomart
Which when she saw, her helmet she vnlaste,
All which when he vnto the end had heard,
All which when she vnto the end had heard,
Whereof when newes to Radigund was brought,
But when they of that yron man had told,
Which when the other heard, she sternly frownd
As when a Tygre and a Lionesse
Which dreadfull sight, when all her warlike traine
Yet when she saw the heapes, which he did make,
Tho when she had his execution stayd,
Where when she saw that lothly vncouth sight,
At last when as to her owne Loue she came,
In which when as she him anew had clad,
Who when him selfe now well recur'd did see,
But when againe they had recouered sence,
Which when the Damzell, who those deadly ends
They stayd their hands, when she thus gan to speake;
Whom when they heard so say, they lookt about,
Where when they saw their foes dead out of doubt,
Tho when as Artegall did Arthure vew,
When I was gone, soone after me she sent
Still when he sought t'approch vnto him ny,
As when the firie-mouthed steeds, which drew
Which when his Ladie from the castles hight
Like raging Ino, when with knife in hand
Or fell Medea, when on Colchicke strand
As this bold woman, when she saw that Damzell there.
As a mad bytch, when as the franticke fit
As Wrong, when it hath arm'd it selfe with might?
Which when those knights had heard, their harts gan earne,
Which when the Damzell neare at hand did spy,
With noyse whereof when as the caytiue carle
Him when the damzell saw fast by her side,
But when the villaine saw her so affrayd,
Crying for helpe aloud. But when as ny
Which when he saw, his yron man he sent,
But when as he would to a snake againe
Crying in vaine for helpe, when helpe was past.
To which when she approched, thus she sayd;
Yet when as foes enforst, or friends sought ayde,
And when in wrath he threats the worlds decay,
And softly royne, when saluage choler gan redound.
So did this mightie Ladie, when she saw
When these two stranger knights arriu'd in place,
Which when as Zele perceiued to abate,
All which when as the Prince had heard and seene,
When they had seene and heard her doome a rights
Who when he none of all those knights did see
When he was readie to his steede to mount
When one in armes she saw, began to fly;
But when her owne two sonnes she had in sight,
When those gainst states and kingdomes do coniure,
To which when now they gan approch in sight,
To whom when tydings thereof came, he streight
Whom when his other fellowes saw, they fled
Long sought the Prince, but when he found no more
Whereof when newes was to that Tyrant brought,
For stil when fit occasion did betyde,
Which vncouth vse when as the Prince perceiued,
One time, when he his weapon faynd to shift,
Whereof when as the Gyant was aware,
Which when the Lady from the Castle saw,
Now when they saw it falne, they eke him greeted all.
Which when the Prince heard tell, his heart gan earne
An huge great Beast it was, when it in length
She comming forth, when as she first beheld
Tho when she saw, that she was forst to fight,
But when he could not quite it, with one stripe
As when the Mast of some well timbred hulke
Whom when he saw on ground, he was full glad,
Whom when she saw so ioyously come forth,
When first to Faery court he saw her wend,
When her that Tyrant did of Crowne depriue;
Whom when they thus distressed did behold,
So when that Knight from perill cleare was freed,
Who when he gaue me armes, in field to fight,
Not so; (quoth he) for yet when time doth serue,
When as necessitie doth it constraine.
As when the wrathfull Boreas doth bluster,
But when as ouerblowen was that brunt,
Whom when those knights so froward and forlore
Tho when they came to the sea coast, they found
But when as nigh vnto the shore they drew,
Which message when Grantorto heard, full fayne
When Artegall she saw in that array,
And gaped like a gulfe, when he did gerne,
Which cruell outrage when as Artegall
As when a skilfull Marriner doth reed
Yet when as fit aduantage he did spy,
Whom when he saw prostrated on the plaine,
Which when the people round about him saw,
When as two old ill fauour'd Hags he met,
For when she wanteth other thing to eat,
Who when they nigh approching, had espyde
And when I gin to feele decay of might,
When Calidore thus first; Haile noblest Knight
When as by chaunce a comely Squire he found,
When he him saw, for no demaunds he staide,
Which haynous sight when Calidore beheld,
But when he felt him shrinke, and come to ward,
When once he felt his foeman to relent;
When as the Carle no longer could sustaine,
Where long he stayed not, when as a Knight
But when Briana saw that drery stound,
But when he saw his foe before in vew,
To follow his first quest, when as he spyde
Which when he saw, his hart was inly child
When so she lagged, as she needs mote so,
Which when I saw, as they me passed by,
Of all which, when as she could nought deny,
Whom when my knight did see so louely faire,
Whereto when as my presence he did spy
For to alight: but when as I was loth,
And left sore wounded: but when her he mist,
But when as her he by no meanes could find,
When forward we should fare, he flat refused
And when he long had him beholding stood,
All which when well Sir Calidore had heard,
Thus when they long had treated to and fro,
To my dread Soueraine, when I it assayd,
Which sorie sight when Calidore did vew
Yet when she fled into that couert greaue,
When Calidore this ruefull storie had
Which when as he perceiu'd, he thus bespake;
Who when he saw his sonne so ill bedight,
When Calidore in seemly good array
The morrow next, when day gan to vplooke,
Where when he saw his faire Priscilla by,
For to haue spoyled her, when Calidore
Who nathelesse, when he the Lady saw
Now when as Phoebus with his fiery waine
But when as Calepine came to the brim,
When day is spent, and rest vs needeth most,
Which answer when the groome returning, brought
As fiercely yet, as when he first begonne,
But when the Saluage saw his labour vaine,
When he beheld the streames of purple blood
When ought he did, that did their lyking gaine.
Now when as Calepine was woxen strong,
Whom when as he thus combred did behold,
But when he lookt about on euery syde,
To whom approching, when as she perceiued
